reviewText:
Early Access Review

First, I would like to confess that I used to pirate games, lots and lots of games. Until one day I came upon Gnomoria, and I pirated it.

This was the game that make me feel guilty about myself, about the fact that I had pirated games. This was the game that help me realize how much efforts and love the devs had put into their games, especially the indie devs, and that having their game pirated is not what they deserve.

I then uninstall the game and swore to never pirate another game again. Unfortunately although I can afford the game, it was difficult to make direct purchase where I live, so I had a friend gift it to me.

With the confession out of the way, now I would like to state the love I have for this game. This is a management game where you program" the gnomes to build an empire of your own. That alone in this game is challenging enough and offers huge replay value
date: the enemies are just icing on the cake IMO.\n\nWhen I said "program"

reviewText:
I first bought this game in June of 2012 on Desura. I played about 150 hours before I activated my Steam key. Since activating I've played almost 180 hours more. The developer has been diligently churning out regular updates and solid communication for the four years I've owned it. He has listened to the community and truly shows how early access can work well.

Gnomoria is one of the greatest base-building games ever. The random start conditions (and extensive options for customized starts) result in a new challenge each time. It's frequently punishing, occassionally frustrating, and consistently fun. Players can enjoy a complex village sim with emergent gameplay that rewards patience and perseverance.

There have been many who have described Gnomoria as Dwarf Fortress Lite
date: which is not entirely inaccurate, but it's (mostly) modern UI and colorful sprites make it far easier to overcome it's learning curve. It's easily one of the friendliest dwarves building fortresses games out there.\n\nI highly recommend Gnomoria.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm on the fence whether I should recommend this game or not. On one hand, i've gotten a decent 20 hours or so of actual play time out of it. On the other hand, I've completely discarded it and returned to Dwarf Fortress, which is free.

I suppose I will recommend it based on the fact that it is decently enjoyable. For me the game was painfully easy to learn and master, which is the only real issue I have with it. There is no real end game. Once you have a sizeable fortress and a decent number of gnomes, all manner of goblins, ogres, beetles, and skeletons will become trivial.

I suppose for 8$, 20 hours is acceptable. Keep in mind that I love this type of game, and have sunk hundreds of hours into games such as Dwarf Fortress, Dungeon Keeper, Majesty, The Guild 2, etc.

However, I loathe Minecraft which has a similar draw of make structures that look pretty." So if you enjoy games like that
date: you may find more appeal in this one after you've conquered the challenges it presents."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGnomes.  Everywhere, gnomes.  This game is frankly amazing for an early access product.  It has a rather solid development rate and offers up so much content for a management style game.  Learning the ropes is a daunting task but an investment in reading through in-game information is all you need to get started...and that's simply part of why this game holds its own so well.  I've invested over a hundred hours in this game at time of posting and I'm liable to invest a hundred more.  The frustrations of the game's innate challenges only seek to spur me on and drive me to build my kingdoms bigger and better.  I can't promise you so many hours of fun, but if this style of game is your bag then the $8 price won't break your wallet.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGnomoria is a game for the people who want to play Minecraft in a RTS setting. Its like an easier Dwarf Fortress, but with graphics. Even so, its by no means easy, just easier. Your first colony will die, and so will your second, and probably your third. But each time its something different, something that was just out of balance this time, but wasn't last time. But you start again, because its not about the destination, its about the journey. Plus you get to complain to all your friends who have no idea what is going on about how your entire colony was overrun by a zombie infection, or starved to death in the dead of winter, or was obliterated by a swarm of Mants. And then next time, you won't that mistake. Gnomoria is easily one of the best purchases I've ever made.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria is an isometric civilization builder. It is clear that Gnomoria is heavily influenced by (because saying 'steals from' is frowned upon) the incredibly popular but also incredibly difficult and intimidating game Dwarf Fortress (which I also love) but makes it more user-friendly and forgiving.

The game can be both brutally punishing and immensely rewarding. Playing your first game will end in inevitable death, probably during the first enemy invasion or your first winter. It is to be expected. As you gradually push further and further with each new civilization you found, you become more attuned to the importance of certain resources and the nuance of city design. Finding ways to optimize building and planning are not taught to you by the game, but learned through bloody trial-and-error. Six or seven games, you'll find your stockpiles bursting before the start of your first winter and the initial goblin invasion cute at best.

Gnomoria is a game where you need to be willing to fail (and fail hard), but also be ready—perhaps even eager—to try again. You'll reach a point where all of your gnomes have tasted delicious goblin sausage and are waiting, steel armor and swords gleaming in the summer sun, sweating with anticipation at the next attack, ready for their next meal to charge into battle with them like the little monsters they are.

I should point out that your gnomes are the monsters in the scenario, not the goblins, and you will be proud of them for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm on the fence whether I should recommend this game or not. On one hand, i've gotten a decent 20 hours or so of actual play time out of it. On the other hand, I've completely discarded it and returned to Dwarf Fortress, which is free.

I suppose I will recommend it based on the fact that it is decently enjoyable. For me the game was painfully easy to learn and master, which is the only real issue I have with it. There is no real end game. Once you have a sizeable fortress and a decent number of gnomes, all manner of goblins, ogres, beetles, and skeletons will become trivial.

I suppose for 8$, 20 hours is acceptable. Keep in mind that I love this type of game, and have sunk hundreds of hours into games such as Dwarf Fortress, Dungeon Keeper, Majesty, The Guild 2, etc.

However, I loathe Minecraft which has a similar draw of make structures that look pretty." So if you enjoy games like that
date: you may find more appeal in this one after you've conquered the challenges it presents."

reviewText:
Gnomoria does little to hide its inspiration. It's an attempt at a more accessible version of the legendarily complex Dwarf Fortress. If you've been following my reviews, you probably know that I place a fair amount of value on accessibility. Adding cute graphics and a, if not modern, at least mouse controlled interface are things I'm very much in favor of.

Unfortunately, the similarly stripped-down complexity ends up losing the unique charm of its inspiration, without actually making the game friendly to those not initiated in the Dorfish ways. Like Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria is a game about systems and trying to keep them in equilibrium. Unlike Dwarf Fortress, it has systems simple enough to solve.

That wouldn't necessarily be a problem if Gnomoria's design moved further afield. But it retains the one save per world and glacial pace. As something to set running in the background and check in on intermittently, it can bring you some entertainment. But it's too slow and too punitive, for too few interesting decisions, to pour the kind of time into that it expects.

reviewText:
Extremely buggy. Worse than it's ever been.

Gnomes regularly fail to path right and starve to death. Gnomes regularly fail to path right and get stuck doing nothing. Pathing in general is atrocious. Gnome AI for stocking items is horrible, they will travel 200 tiles distance to grab a single item, take it 200 tiles to stock it, and repeat, when theres dozens of wheelburrows, buckets, and sacks laying around.

The game is playable... up until you get some bug seriously ♥♥♥♥ing you over. And it can ♥♥♥♥ you over massively. Akin to wasting real life days worth of played time. The only way to manage avoiding this is manually going into the save files to make backups because the game wont let you do it from the menu's.

There are a ton of other flaws, but I can't really complain about those. Their cosmetic. I could accept the cosmetic / UI issues if the base game itself would at least ♥♥♥♥ing play right, but alas, it doesn't.

TL;DR A potentially great game ruined by cripplingly damaging bugs.

RIP Gnomoria.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCasual version of Dwarf Fortress that seems to lack some of the finer mechanics. I feel like there needs to be a triple speed function instead of just normal and 2x. Your gnomes won't really think of using other workshops if you build them after starting an order and they usually try to make everything out of wood. The mason shop will sit empty as they furiously use one carpenter bench to fill out an order for 8 chairs and tables. The UI is pretty good, only thing that bothered me was you can't right click for orders when you're highlighting a stockpile. Combat is alright but you have to manually access the event logs to read the fight details in a tiny window. Overall a pretty solid game if you can't get into DF because of its interface.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This the best version of what I'd call an Accessible Dwarf Fortress".

Pros:
Relatively easy to pick up and learn.  The wiki helps.
In depth terrain generation controls
Fairly intuitive controls (could be better
date:
but far better than some that come to mind)
Very nice isometric graphics
Cons:
This game (especially early on) has a lot of waiting
recommended:
but that sort of comes with this genre of games.  The fastest you can move time forward is 2x speed.
Music is repetitive.  Some sounds can be particularly jarring or otherwise seem to clash with the game's atmosphere.
No combat animations.  Unless you pause the game very frequently during fighting to check the gnomes' health it can be difficult to tell if a battle between your gnomes and an enemy is going poorly or not.
For all the DF-likes I've seen on Steam
hoursPlayed: this one is the best."

Early Access Review

Honey Badger slaughtered half of my population. 11/10.

But in all seriousness, it's a fun game.
The amount of options you have before you as far as create and manipulate is wide and varied. The controls are good (the U.I. is a little clunky, but very workable). It's an all-around fun, challenging, frustrating experience that I'm already hooked on.
The only issue is a few minor problems with actions being performed in the order you want them or some of your commands being ignored, but most of these can easily be resolved.

I would highly recommend that people that enjoy games like minecraft or terraria and are interested in a top-down god-game with a similar feel try this game out. Just make sure you look over a few tutorials and have the wiki handy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria is a surprisingly fun and addictive game. If you've ever been curious about Dwarf Fortress, but were intimidated by the lack of UI and graphics, Gnomoria is a fantastic game to jump into. Orders you give to your gnomes will be followed according to the guidelines you set. You do not directly control them, but you affect how they behave by determining the gnome's professions, priorities,  and other parameters you impose. It becomes an extremely fun balancing act of figuring out exactly how to acheive true efficiency while also struggling to plan ahead. The more expansive and 'worthy' your empire becomes, the greater dangers arrive to destroy it. It takes hours to finally feel like you've gotten a foothold in the world you've generated, but when you do, you feel a great sense of pride in what your tiny gnome society has accomplished.

The only gripes I would have would be the lack of variety in environments as well as the flora and fauna. New biomes as well as new animals and trees would make this game way more replayable. Also, this game has no form of tutorial so the learning curve is quite steep. It took me 3 different restarts before I fully understood the importance of key aspects of the game like action priorities, training a strong military, and proper item storage to name a few. The wiki and video tutorials should definitely be used when first starting off. Beyond that, the game is definitely worth the eight dollar inevestment and is worth your time. If you've ever been inquisitive about these types of strategy games, Gnomoria is a charming and enjoyable place to start.

TLDR: If you like sandbox village games heavy on micromanagement - get it!

While it does not quite have the complexity of Dwarf Fortess, it is the closest thing I have been able to find so far.  The world mechanics themselves are quite marvellous, but there is no real personality" to the gnomes beyond what you project onto them
date: you can't see what they are thinking
recommended: there are no fun personality conflicts ending in bloodshed.  There are no cats.\n\nIt takes a little patience to pick up at first
hoursPlayed:
you can count on your first few games ending within a year or two as orcs and/or viscious wild animals kill your sweet little gnomes.

But if you push through you'll soon be able to build defenses to withstand these early problems long enough to run into entirely new and exciting ways to end your little gnomes lives.

Word of advice - when experimenting with water

reviewText: Good concept, everything works well, except that the combat system is garbage. Gnomes run to their deaths at the first sign of ennemies regardless of personal safety. There should be an override action to tell gnomes what to do on an individual basis other than the generic profession checkboxes. SInce Combat is a big part of the game, it should be possible to gather whatever gnomes you wish in groups through a selection box, like say all strategy games out there, and click on an ennemy to attack, or move away to safety, as opposed to the system that is in place now, which is, to say the least, garbage. I'm sure it's possible to code this in such a way that you can put the current automation programming on hold with an override option, and then revert back to automation once satisifed with whatever you wanted to do in the first place. Sadly this is not so. Buy this game if you have nohing better to do, in my opinion it's unfinished and unpolished. I don't think there was a proper update on this in a long while, its a shame because this game has a lot of potential. Is it playable? Yes. Is it fun? For a while, if you dont mind saving a lot and alt tab quitting to exit the game because there's no better way to exit this without saving. For a micromanagement game this fails miserably to satisfy my ocd. It's a shame because the building aspect is actually fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, starting with the obvious: you might heard or know of another game called Dwarf Fortress. This is indeed very similar, yet it's very worth your time in its own. Think of this as DF a hundred times more relaxed and less complex, but a thousand times prettier. I would call it a friendlier Dwarf Fortress.

Now, if you really don't know anything about either game, this is a management / sandbox game. You start with a crew of settler gnomes, and that's pretty much it; you're thrown into the wild and after that it depends on you; these gnomes can and will use materials around them at your command, build structures as complex as you can imagine, fight your battles and of course, deplete your alcohol and foods. Doing these simple things plus all the intrincate delicacies will take most of your time, and as you expect from any good game... you won't know how much time you have sunk in here.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATE: With Dwarf fortress newest release 42.05, it really blows Gnomoria out of the water in terms of depth. Still recommended, just less so. I've probably spent 2-3 times the hours played in Dwarf fortress than Gnomoria since I last wrote the Gnomoria review, so I definitely prefer DF.

If you loved Dwarf Fortress, but wish it was just a little easier on the interface and the eyes, look no further than Gnomoria.

Gnomoria vs. Dwarf Fortress Comparison:

Interface: Average versus Horrible.
Graphics: Average versus Horrible.
Overall Depth: Good versus Amazing.
Combat Depth: Average versus Great (Upgraded DF's combat depth due to recent release that have mercenaries and more usable war animals).
Mechanism/Trap Customization: Average versus Amazing
Simulation/Realism: Average versus Amazing.
Learning Curve: High versus Colossal. (2 hrs versus 12 hrs)
Pacing: Superb versus Good.

-----

Further comment on pacing: Gnomoria imho has amazing pacing, it takes forever to achieve things in Gnomoria, but it doesn't feel that way until you stare at the clock and realize you just lost 5 hours setting up 5 rooms because of the four intervening goblin raids with Ogre support and food shortage. Yet, you were having a blast and didn't notice how much time went by. This sort of time loss never happens to me these days; it says a lot that this game is able to recreate it.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Good concept, everything works well, except that the combat system is garbage. Gnomes run to their deaths at the first sign of ennemies regardless of personal safety. There should be an override action to tell gnomes what to do on an individual basis other than the generic profession checkboxes. SInce Combat is a big part of the game, it should be possible to gather whatever gnomes you wish in groups through a selection box, like say all strategy games out there, and click on an ennemy to attack, or move away to safety, as opposed to the system that is in place now, which is, to say the least, garbage. I'm sure it's possible to code this in such a way that you can put the current automation programming on hold with an override option, and then revert back to automation once satisifed with whatever you wanted to do in the first place. Sadly this is not so. Buy this game if you have nohing better to do, in my opinion it's unfinished and unpolished. I don't think there was a proper update on this in a long while, its a shame because this game has a lot of potential. Is it playable? Yes. Is it fun? For a while, if you dont mind saving a lot and alt tab quitting to exit the game because there's no better way to exit this without saving. For a micromanagement game this fails miserably to satisfy my ocd. It's a shame because the building aspect is actually fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GNOMORIA is great. Is a DWARF FORTRESS with better graphics, less events, and easier to learn.
That said, it´s EASIER TO LEARN THAN DWARF FORTRESS, not EASY... expect a challenge: you WILL have to figure out how things work, and until you do you will be beaten senseless by goblin hordes.
After you fail misaribly a few times (because you will), you´ll start to work on better strategies that WILL defeat entire hordes of goblins without loosing even one Gnome: building and testing floor traps with a 10 level fall, building pistols and ammo, fully steel armored gnomes in front to hold enemies, statue building for trading, specializing a Gnome in Tinkering only to have access to inventions, duplicating farm groves... not for the weak willed!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I could never get into Dwarf Fortress because of the interface & because I don't have as much time on my hands as I'd like. Gnomoria has enough content for a filthy casual like me to be able to pick up & tinker with, without squinting at a ton of ASCII screens or fiddling with mods to enhance the graphics.The Gnomoria art style could be considered basic, but I like the look of it and it does the job.
Being time-light, I need a game I can pick up & play straight off, and you can do that to a certain extent in Gnomoria but your little kingdom won't last long. It really could do with a tutorial mode, but the game is Early Access, and as the devs are patching and adding content it would probably make a tutorial a bit of a pain to implement. Maybe some popup gameplay tips could be implemented instead?

TL;DR - Simplified version of Dwarf Fortress. If you ike the idea of that, take a punt.

I give it 4 out of 5 yak skulls.

A nice indie game that has not yet reached it's full potential but has me engrossed in it for 100 hours already.

Gnomoria has been closely linked to dwarf fortress, and is in the same genre as minecraft and terraria where you build blocks out of resources like dirt, stone and metal.
You lead a group of gnomes to forge your own empire, harvesting resources and constructing buildings while fighting off various enemies.

At this time Gnomoria isn't finished but it is a steal at it's current price of US$8. Wait for a sale and it will go lower.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its like Minecraft meets the Sims meets Dwarf Fortress.

Resource gathering and crafting like Minecraft.  Dig holes, carve stairs, collect and smelt ores, harvest trees, collect food, create tools, weapons, armor, traps, furniture, and more.

You don't do things, you tell your gnomes to do it, kinda like the Sims.  And the best part is, you can set the task or an area of tasks and the best qualified gnome or gnomes will do it.  Clear cut that forest!  Mine that 10 x 24 area!  Make 20 chestplates!  And the more robust your kingdom, the more likely you are to attract more suckers!  Ahem.  Gnomes, more gnomes.

Invasions, enemies, death and dismemberment.  The combat logs show quite a bit of data and some rather unexpected things can happen, unexpected and permanent things.
So and so slashes the goblin's left arm.  Goblin drops its shield.
Goblin stabs past the cuirass, through the chest, through the ribs, and into the heart.  So and so is bleeding.  So and so is dead.
Honey Badger bites so and so's leg and tears it off.  So and so lost their left leg. (permanently for now)

But dismemberment doesn't mean death, but it does mean limited functionality for your gnome.  Do you let the one legged wonder hobble around and craft in the workshop, leave their job as is and wonder how good a one armed woodsman is, or do you tell them to strip and go attack that bear's stomach from the inside?

It might look limiting at first because the surface world doesn't go on seemingly forever like Minecraft, or all that far at all.  However, it does go down quite far (-100 and still digging).  I haven't seen how far myself, but think the Mines of Moria from LoTR.  Yes, treasures can be found deep, but so can other dangers...  Bring lots of torches!

Anyway, I've logged roughly 40 or so hours, and even in its rough and unfinished stage, it is a blast that I can't get enough of.  Well worth the investment in this indie title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this game for those searching for a game similar to DF (and a lot of patience). Among indie games, I find this more polished and fun than others. Recently, I've seen many early access games on managing a town/castle like this but Gnomoria is the one that has basic features implented for now.
Gnomoria is also quite challenging, 45 hours of playtime is merely at the stage of grasping the basics of this game. For me, it took 5 hours to understand digging and building, 10 more hours to understand creating items and extra 25 to know I was doing it all wrong.

On the other hand, this game is rather unfriendly; no tutorials, no explanation except a little bit of text that can be found in Help menu. Around 30-40 different buttons to utilize, yet without any description on what it does. Some are straight forward, setting up a farm area is one. But other buttons such as Dig Stairs Up and Mine Stairs Down may be a little bit confusing combined with 3D textile map in which tiles overlap each other.
For those who likes to rage quit or play very casually (playing most games on normal or easy difficulty), Gnomoria is not recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Gnomoria for a while now and it's the game I keep coming back to.  Regular updates and very fun content give good replay value and once you learn the mechanics, starting over after a wild honey badger dismembers your colony, or when that first goblin turns out to be a kung fu master, is a lot easier.

I've been burned ALOT by early access games that have gotten abandoned, are too buggy to play, or that promise a lot of great things that you find are not in the game yet when you buy it.  Gnomoria has delivered in spades on what was promised and remains one of the best early access titles that I have purchased.  Well worth the price of admission!  8 bucks, are you kidding me,  SOLD!

If you liked Dwarf Fortress style games, but are looking for something that is more approchable without the vertical learning curve of DF, then this would be a good experience for you.  If you already are familiar with Dwarf Fortress, then most of the mechanics will be immediatly familiar.

And if you've never tried either this is definately a good starting point, though read some guides.

Great job RoboBob!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A nice indie game that has not yet reached it's full potential but has me engrossed in it for 100 hours already.

Gnomoria has been closely linked to dwarf fortress, and is in the same genre as minecraft and terraria where you build blocks out of resources like dirt, stone and metal.
You lead a group of gnomes to forge your own empire, harvesting resources and constructing buildings while fighting off various enemies.

At this time Gnomoria isn't finished but it is a steal at it's current price of US$8. Wait for a sale and it will go lower.

Early Access Review

I got this game as a gift and at first I wasn't so sure about it. I thought it was like all the other 2D building games. But it's so much more. The whole experience is charming. At first I had no idea what to do, it had a lot of confusing gameplay, but once you right clicked, it had everything as a shortcut. It gets more simple as you go along. I started my first game, and I already wanted to make a new one because I knew I could do better!  Practice makes perfect!
Be prepared to have a buddy sit and help you, or have a wiki open!
This game has so much things in it, it is definitley worth the 8 dollars!
Every world and gnome are unique (and adorable!)
This game is deep! (pun intended)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really love this game because it's a a challenging sandbox strategy mash-up. Some times it can be frustrating when bad things happen, but other than that it's a really enjoyable experience. I love seeing the little dudes run around doing my bidding, and it's especially hilarious if you save the combat logs and read those.

Be warned: this game does not hold your hand, so you'll have to either figure things out through trial and error, or look up a guide online to get the basics down. That being said, it's still worth it. Don't be afraid of the 'Early Access'; it's still a robust game that can keep you entertained for hours.  As of writing this I'm at just under 90 hours, and I feel like I've barely scratched the surface (which may or may not be from restarting more than a couple times....)

Be wary of digging too deeply and too gredily...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, The Kingdom of Tiera has thrived through at least three years of Development with only six people lost and 20 Alive, My Kingdom is built within an Mountain which is surrounded by thick walls (2 blocks thick). Of late, the goblins have took the arm of one of my most prized builder (Who made gifts for the goblins) , she died shortly after losing it, but in the fall was a greater lost. In the fall of the second year, my strongest warrior sacrificed herself to fend off an first-sighted Mant, after the battle she sustained her wound for at least 2 hours, slowly bleeding out without the care of the nurse, which I later blamed for her death, since she refused to treat her (R.I.P Pixel, the greatest warrior there ever was).

On the sides of our mountains, there are fields which possess strawberries, cotton, and wheat, which provides my people their needs all year long, fill the storehouse to the brim with food and cloth, also fill everyone's room with a bed. A nearby mountain has been turned into a mine, where we mine for copper and metal to suit our soldiers at arms with good equipment such as armor and weapons, which allows to them to face off against the Goblins and Wildlife. Our Soldiers are our pride and strength, making Tiera an strong nation, They train daily at the Training grounds in hope of being as great as Pixel, who killed 10 goblins, 2 honey badgers, and a Dirt golem but was sadly killed by a mant and a careless nurse.

This Kingdom still lives on in these lands to this day, which may someday conquer over all foes who challenges it as well as the land of the Severed land merchant kingdom and the Goblin kingdom. May Tiera be the mightiest kingdom that ever stood
date: Coraina's trade will never beat it's strength of two thousand soldiers" - King Jake Windti of Jakltina from Tretogo Mercenaries.\n\nGame 9/10
hoursPlayed: a boy with dreams of making games."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why buy an ant farm when you can have a Gnome farm?

Most certainly worth the cheap price! If you're up for a challenging city/town builder similar to Dwarf Fortress, this is the game for you.
There were many times I had encountered bugs that rendered the game unplayable, such as Gnomes being persistently idle and refusing to work, but there are usually workarounds to these.

PROS:
- Addicting once you get the hang of it
- Challenging gameplay
- Catchy soundtrack

CONS:
- AI pathing/priority/combat mechanics still need to be improved
- It is only a matter of time before you encounter some sort of bug
- No tutorial (or tooltips/info)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great little village/kingdom management game inspired by Dwarf Fortress and several other games.  If, like me, you loved DF but found it a bit too complicated, then Gnomoria's definitely worth a shot.  For an Early Access game, it's got a lot of stuff to play with.  There's plenty of content to keep you entertained for quite some time, and more is added on a regular basis.  There are plenty of options to customize the game to your liking, and mods are also available.

If you're not too familiar with this type of game, I strongly recommend trying the demo first.  Gnomoria is definitely not for everyone, especially those who expect to be able to jump right in without doing some reading first.  The demo is available at gnomoria.com.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GNOMORIA is great. Is a DWARF FORTRESS with better graphics, less events, and easier to learn.
That said, it´s EASIER TO LEARN THAN DWARF FORTRESS, not EASY... expect a challenge: you WILL have to figure out how things work, and until you do you will be beaten senseless by goblin hordes.
After you fail misaribly a few times (because you will), you´ll start to work on better strategies that WILL defeat entire hordes of goblins without loosing even one Gnome: building and testing floor traps with a 10 level fall, building pistols and ammo, fully steel armored gnomes in front to hold enemies, statue building for trading, specializing a Gnome in Tinkering only to have access to inventions, duplicating farm groves... not for the weak willed!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I could never get into Dwarf Fortress because of the interface & because I don't have as much time on my hands as I'd like. Gnomoria has enough content for a filthy casual like me to be able to pick up & tinker with, without squinting at a ton of ASCII screens or fiddling with mods to enhance the graphics.The Gnomoria art style could be considered basic, but I like the look of it and it does the job.
Being time-light, I need a game I can pick up & play straight off, and you can do that to a certain extent in Gnomoria but your little kingdom won't last long. It really could do with a tutorial mode, but the game is Early Access, and as the devs are patching and adding content it would probably make a tutorial a bit of a pain to implement. Maybe some popup gameplay tips could be implemented instead?

TL;DR - Simplified version of Dwarf Fortress. If you ike the idea of that, take a punt.

I give it 4 out of 5 yak skulls.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

YOU NEED TO BUY THIS GAME>>>>>

I have tried countless Dwarf Fortress style games and none of them come close to Gnomoria's level of detail and fair challenge. There is a learning curve if you dont read guides online, there are times you will completely work yourself into a corner, and there are times you will scratch your head and go why isn't this working the way I thought it would." But everything in this game is built with a reliance on something else. Learning those relationships and how to maximize your productivity is exceptionally fun (in my opinion) especially when the game is so fair.

Every time I've lost a gnome
recommended: or dug too deep too quick (you'll see why) I would sit back
hoursPlayed: cry a little about the last 20 hours that I just burned into the ground
voteText:
and say "ok... that's fair... lets try again."

If you've ever sunk 200 turns into Civilization after swearing you'd go to bed this game is no different. "Just another 10 minutes" always turns into hours of doing things! Alot of these games have moments of busy work then a sit back and watch factor but I have ALWAYS found something to do with every minute in Gnomoria.

I know this might just sound like a gush about the game but I absolutely love this title and the dev is still updating frequently. You owe it to yourself to buy Gnomoria. You owe it to yourself to sink a few months into it.

As Shia says: JUST. DO. IT."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGnomoria is a game were you controll (as in there jobs) a group of gnoms can do anything from farming to crafting or to building amazing castles or dangerous dungeons. You need to have them build a kingdom ( or queendom dempending on what you want) to thrive and prosper through the peralis world while defending yourself through theifs and monsters that want to plunder your materials and crafts or just murder everyone. You can also have them build stalls to attrack merchants as your kingdoms wealth increases and buy and sell things like animals food and materials. Although its a pretty neat game the gnomes AI on how to complete tasks like replacing floor tiles is a bit wonky. Your gnomes will comonly get stuck and die if left to there own devices so you do have to mannage them frequently. Plus they dont like to build things like workshops if theres other jobs that need to be done. All in all it is a decent game with a few major bugs that will be worked out eventually and so on.

reviewText:
This is kind of my favorite game. I don't know why, because it's not at all what I normally play and I don't know why I bought it all those years ago since I thought the whole idea of 'early access' was just begging for scammers, but years later and I still love it.
I started playing this on a very old laptop that died, then a very old desktop that died, and now on a super amazing new desktop. I've never encountered any glitches in the game on any of those devices.
Other people are complaining because the developer never added... something. I don't remember any specific promises. Instead the game was opened to mods and released.The mods are like endless free dlc packs and completely overhaul it into entirely new experiences. It's awesome, I don't know what promises made that would have been better than that.
The only complaint i have is that it takes a very long time to generate a map. I would say sometimes an hour. I just set it up to generate and go out for a while.

reviewText: I bought this game for $15 and it was worth every penny. I haven't had all the time i wish I had to do everything I wanted to yet in this game but its bounds are almost limitless. I hear what people are saying about the devs giving up and how it could have been so much more, and all that is true. However the reason they dropped it was because the game was not getting enough attention. They were tanking on money so they had to move on. Maybe if enough new people started showing interest then they would pick it back up? I dont really know though. Even still what they have left is a great game and I think people are being a little narrow minded in saying it couldve been more. I mean look at it. Enjoy what you got guys this game is fantastic. Don't look at it for what you wish it could be soak it in for what it is. Stop complaining and enjoy a really great game. Overall give it a buy; it really is worth the money

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never played dwarf fortress and so cannot compare gnomoria to it.  That said i'm a big fan of every city-building or strategy games of quality on steam and this one is definitely part of them.  At first, don't be fooled with the early access tag, this game feels much more complete then a few other titles i bought that claimed to be a finished product.  Add to that the fact that the developer constantly update the game.  Now for the gameplay the game can be confusing at first but the help tab in the main interface can answer most of your questions and will teach you the basics.  For the rest well it's up to you to discover the deeper features of the game which from my point of view makes it interesting.  The also have a very adjustable difficulty, which allows you to play the game as a city-building sim without any combat or harm to your growing city to an extreme survival experience where the threats to end your fledling settlement are plenty.

In short, gnomoria has all you need to please all kind of strategy/city-building type of players and it's replayabilty with it's customizable maps, various difficulty levels and frequent new content makes it worth every dollar spent on this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria: a gateway game to Dwarf Fortress? A shamless clone with graphics? I enjoy both games in their own right, having sunk hours (days) into both, starting with Dwarf Fortress.

Gnomoria started off fairly humbly on features and gameplay but with regular weekly updates is growing into a different game in its own right.

If you hanker for the days of Bullfrog games, enjoy simulations or found the idea of Dwarf Fortress enticing but too much effort then you should try Gnomoria.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well bloody done.

i started this game when it was in early Beta and it was already more pollished than a fully released game. (For example the failures of Citadels and Stronghold 3).   It was perfectly stable, clean and best of all, fun.  This gnome management game has only improved since then.  Gnomoria is a top down, micro management game all about the balance between defence and your economy.  To help describe this game, it may be easier to think of it as a simplified dwarf fortress.  So far Gnomoria has recieved numerous and frequent updates throughout the entiety of its developement.  (As you may have noticed, this fact is quite rare.)

Graphics:
The graphics in this game are nothing special.  That being said, its simple, 2d and nice to look at for quite some time.  It fits the gameplay and overall feel of the game.  It doesn't become an eyesore after a few hours like a bad minecraft texture pack.  The only real complaint a perfectionist could have with the graphics is the animation of gnomes moving through tiles, But trust me when i say it irrelavent for this type of game.

The Gameplay:
This is why you play this game.  All the way from the growth rate of trees, to the construction pathways for needed tools and weapons.  The only item that needs work is the settable priority for starage zones and work benches (which the developer has been and continues to work on.)
The core gameplay is all about setting tasks and then the allocation of gnomes to that type of task.  More like running a business than a typical rts.
I must advise all new players build a terrain wall around thier settlement and get the basics before managing combat.

Strengths.
As addictive as minecraft.
Once you set up your economy and defences, its quite easy to play whilst watching a movie or anime.

Weaknesses:
For those who are not patient, do not bother. Completing a task can take days ingame and real time hours.
Can be annoying to debug why a specific task is not being completed.


Summary:
One of the most unique games that i have played in the genre.  Once you get the hang of it, its an excellent game. (just do not expect your first try to do anything other than fail miserably.)
I have easily put over 50 hours into this game.  Its amazing to see a game in beta that is already near the top of its genre.

As the value of your kingdom increases, you will attract more Gnomads"

votesFunny: and Anno) was a big inspiration for the game. The developer clearly states this in the FAQ on the game's official website. This game does not have the sheer
commentsCount: unbridled complexity of Dwarf Fortress. It makes up for this by being much more accessible while still having a good amount of depth
column16: and having its own innovations and ways of doing things compared to DF.\n\nNow

column18: so you will need to either spend the first few hours experimenting to get a feel for things
column19: or consult a guide/wiki while you are playing to speed things up. If that's a dealbreaker for you

column25: which actually speeds everything up. There's also only one biome available right now
column26: but there are plans to add some more eventually (the two specifically mentioned in the development roadmap are "Desert" and "Jungle").\n\nThe game is under active development

column29: the game is very stable and the vast majority of bugs are a mere annoyance. There's nothing truly gamebreaking to worry about.\n\nA common question that comes up on the Steam discussion forums is "how does this game compare to Towns?". I have not actually played Towns
column30: but I know enough to at least say that the gimmick of "attracting Heroes and having them clear out a huge dungeon for you so your citizens can bring up the loot" is not present in Gnomoria. You have to dig your own mines

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria is very similar to Dwarf Fortress, except that it is extremely simplified. This is both good and bad as it is much more enjoyable to the casual gamer, but it lacks the depth and detail of its predecessor.

In Gnomoria, you manage a group of gnomes while building a new settlement. You mine rocks, gems, and ore as well as harvest trees and plant farms. Raise a herd of yaks, emus, or alpacas and use the various products to feed your gnomes, craft new items, and trade with nearby villages.

Overall, I have thoroughly enjoyed the game, and I look forward to further releases.

reviewText:
By way of content, this game is a lot like Dwarf Fortress without the asymptotic learning curve at the beginning (there's still one, mind you).

The mod support that came out in late early access definitely helps the community build more upon the base game but at the same time allows the developer to throw out the majority of the future plans listed on the game's website during early access because the game is technically finished.

reviewText:
I like Dwarf Fortress. Well... No, that's not accurate... I want to like Dwarf Fortress.
Wat makes it difficult to like is the ungainly controls, and learning curve that's a mile high. I don't mind losing so much as I mind not having the foggiest idea of how to get from here to that point.
Gnomoria makes things easier to read, visually, than Dwarf Fortress even with the best of tile packs installed. It's *just* intuitive enough to make it possible to reach your goals even if you haven't memorized exactly what order you have to build all of your parts in, to get there.
Highly recommended for anyone who wants a simple, plug-and-play experience that very accurately replicates Dwarf Fortress, except in a more approachable fashion.

reviewText:
I bought this game after seeing it on the steam front page and doing a large amount of research on it.  I'm a fan of strategy games and building sims and was looking for a new one to get into.  I read that Gnomoria was like Dwarf Fortress light and I was intrigued.  I've wanted for a long time to get into Dwarf Fortress but have been repeatedly thwarted by the downright arcane interface.  I just can't get past it.

That being said, this game still does not hold your hand.  There is no tutorial at all, you are simply dropped into the game and expected to figure it out through trial and error, or lots and lots of internet research like I did.  It reminded me a lot of my time learning to play Don't Starve, another game that I absolutely love.

I'm not going to talk too much about the details of the game because honestly nobody is going to read this anyway and there are plenty of other resources that discuss that, but I am going to say that I like how the game does not really force you into fighting.  The enemies do not get stronger as time goes on (though you can switch a setting so that they do if you want) but rather they only get stronger as your kingdom value increases or as you dig deeper (depending on enemy type).  This means that there is no ticking clock" component to the game (again
date: unless you want there to be) and you are free to just build if you want only really running into danger if you let your military fall too far behind the other aspects of your kingdom.  If you dig too deep too fast or build too much too soon without developing your military you are in for a bad time.\n\nOr
recommended: you can just turn enemies off and ignore combat altogether.\n\nIf you are a fan of strategy games
hoursPlayed: building sims
voteText: economy sims
helpfulPercent: and just sandbox games in general where the only objective is really just to build what you want
votesHelpful: then I think that the $15 is stupidly cheap for the number of entertainment hours you will get from Gnomoria.  I know it was for me."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun game that will keep you occupied for hours. The game has a steep learning curve, but is very rewarding once you learn the basics.

When starting your game you have the option to choose how large the map is, how flat it is, and how steep the terrain is.
You also have the added bonus of choosing a difficulty to start on. I say bonus because not only can you select basic difficulties but you can also go into the settings and mess around with the types of monsters (you can even remove monsters altogether), their strength, how many come at a time, and how often they come.
This is just the customization for your map, I haven't even gotten to the game itself yet!

In the interest of keeping this brief I will list just a few different things I like about the game:
- Great customization (pretty much everything you do will be unique to the way you like to play)
- Changeable music styles (It's actually the same music but you can change it between an 8-bit classic" style and a more modern "orchestral")
- Good for casual or serious gaming (With the difficulty settings you can make the game relatively easy and peaceful or very hard and challenging)
- Lots of replayability (I play the game quite a bit and have created many different levels
date: I have yet to run out of things to do or new ideas to try)\n- Sandbox (If you can think it
recommended: you can build it. Making a kingdom? I suggest the "Huge" map size)\n- Early Access Game (Unlike numerous abysmal Early Access games
hoursPlayed: this one feels very finished and the developer is still working to make it even better)\n\nI might also add that there are many guides on Steam and the internet that can explain some of the more difficult parts of the game. Aside from a few minor bugs that still need to be ironed out
voteText: this game is very entertaining and well worth the price."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Synopsis: Inspired primarily by Dwarf Fortress (http://www.bay12games.com/dwarves/), this is an isometric 2D building game where you start with a small group of Gnomes and issue them orders to build, mine, craft, harvest and defend themselves. As you improve their new home, more Gnomes will arrive that you must feed, provide shelter for and issue orders to.

I'm really enjoying this game when I play it. I can pause at any time and issue orders, which is a real plus for me because I can use all the time I wish to plan several moves ahead. The pause feature also allows me to play this game as I do other tasks around the house or while at work.

Be advised, there are no animations as of the last time I played it. Also, the control interface still needs polish. Once you get used to it it's not too bad, but it's takes some time to achieve that comfort zone.

I also have some issue with the 2D terrain where I'm not always sure how terrain on one level will interact with the terrain above and below it, particularly with trying to place/remove dirt and stairs. Might just be me though.

Developers are making progress and have not put this one on the back-burner as is happening with too many pre-releases on Steam lately.

Usual advice is that you should peruse youtube for as much footage of the game, filtering for the most recent videos for the latest release versions, before you buy. Also try to get it on sale. When it's on sale, it's a no brainer.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs a huge fan of Dwarf Fortress, I picked this game up about a year ago and I haven't regretted it for a moment. If you're not familiar with Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria is a game about building a place for your gnomes to work, eat, drink, sleep, and live their lives. Some improvements on Dwarf Fortress are that the UI is very intuitive, and I can craft goods out of a specific material and automatically set workshops to craft missing components of an object I'm building. I've also been happy with the regular update pace, although unfortunately this game is not moddable (at least at the moment). All in all, if you're interested in this sort of game, I'd recommend buying it. At the moment I'm writing this, it's on sale for 50% off or $3.99, and at that price it's a steal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A rare gem among many others like itself. Gnomoria is still under development but that doesn't stop it from being fun. Updates are frequent and the developer is ingratiated with the community, often seen discussing game mechanics on the forums with other users. As for the game itself, it's virtually Dwarf Fortress with a mouse GUI. Features an 8-bit or midi-orchestral custom soundtrack which will graft itself into your grey matter.

For all the building you will be doing, the meat of the game lies within the combat, and squads. Uniforms are made(you designate the material and quality of each piece of armor and weapon that uniform will use), soldiers use these uniforms and perks, formations use soldiers and their own perks as well, and finally squads are made designating formation, and what gnomes will be in what position.

Now to clear up my earlier statement, this game doesn't try to become Dwarf Fortress with mouse support, but it is obviously heavily inspired. Do not come looking for the complexity that DF contains, though for finished releases and beyond, I can't say. Enemies are unique in their own way. Golems spawn underground in the dark, with their strength determined by the depth. Goblins and the like will spawn ground level at the edge of the map. Animals as well, but you typically see goblins during night or morning whereas animals are more popular during the day. Mants will raid you with strength and numbers based on your food stockpile.

I've followed the development of this game for over half a year and I can honestly say it's been one of the few early access games(had it before it was on steam) that I've never had one regret purchasing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria, how I hate thee.  I come back to you again and again and can't get enough.  You suck up my time.  Time that I meant to use to get to know other games.  Yet, I always return to you...

I love the idea of Dwarf Fortress, it's fantastic and quirky.  But ASCII graphics?  I put up with ASCII graphics back in the early 80s.  Gnomoria removes that problem.

Pros:  if you like sandbox village management games.  Yes.  You should buy this game now.  Why are you still reading this?

Other Pros:  I realize Gnomoria is defined by Dwarf Fortress (they are the same game) right down to the quirky names for legendary items.  For instance, my cook creates a legendary sandwich.  The sandwich gets a name.  That name is the Hateful Spite.  You build your underground (or above ground) village.  You start up production of tables and chairs and various and sundry things that you will place in your Gnomish Colony (it's had to call it a city because I've only ever got up to 45 gnomes) to raise the value of your little colony to attract more gnomes...and badies who come to steal, kill, and destroy what you worked so hard to make.  (you can turn that off by the way)

Cons:
Don't expect amazing, splendiforious graphics of amazing splendiforousness.  Minecraft graphics and Gnomoria graphics...it's kind've a toss up as to which is better.  I think Minecraft has an edge in my humble opinion.

The balancing of attackers to defenders and the rate at which they appear is...not good.  If you approach the game knowing that the badies will eventually beat your gnomes to a bloody pulp you're golden.  I dislike putting myself into that mindset.  It would be nice if the developers put in an in-game adjustable scale for those times you just want the badies to leave you alone, but still allow for those times when you're ready to let Gnomeggedon begin--and see if you're preparations can handle it.

The interface does take some getting used to.  I suggest using the menu at the bottom instead of the right mouse menu.

At the moment 3 December 2013, the game has some serious lag issues once all your items approach 8-12k.  I do hope that gets fixed.

Summary:
It's amazing!  This game, in my opinion, is better than Drawf Fortress, mostly because the graphical user interface allows for easier access while still keeping most of the concepts, quirkiness, and spirit of the original.

A very fun game that will keep you occupied for hours. The game has a steep learning curve, but is very rewarding once you learn the basics.

When starting your game you have the option to choose how large the map is, how flat it is, and how steep the terrain is.
You also have the added bonus of choosing a difficulty to start on. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game a lot. It is, overall, a simple graphic update to dwarf fortress that is a tad dumbed down. That said it is one of the most complex town/ colonization sim I have played that keeps you entertained for a long time. I played it before it was on steam and was excited to see it come out finally, but since it got on steam there hasn't been a whole lot of development. I'm really waiting for the end product to show up. As it stands once you have built everything you run out of things to do because you can literally walk away from the computer and your town will do fine most of the time. Its worth buying as is, and I can really see the potential in the end product. But its like getting halfway through a book and finding out the author of the series you are halfway through died without writing the last books, and unlike Robert Jordan, the author didn't leave notes that someone else could follow to write the ending to a monumental series.

Pros
-Manage a settlement of gnomes
-You can micromanage as much as you want
-Simple graphics, but not a text game
-Addictive, way too much of my life
-Challenging
-Customizable difficulties
-Diplomacy looks promising if it ever gets improved, like maybe I want to conduct a raid on a neighboring goblin kingdom instead of just insulting them

Cons
-Stupid zombies and beetles
-Steep learning curve
-Not much developement on the game, snails pace
-Produces a lot of activity that I never get from other games on my CPU
-No tiered crafting system- the Gnomes can make everything as soon as there are materials and the skills involved don't change the end product enough that it matters- only skills that improve anything are fighting skills, and farming.
-Trade doesn't really change over time- you get wealthier but your neighbors stay the same

I realize I have a lot of cons but some of them I enjoy like the steep learning curve, and just the way the game works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria is not Dwarf Fortress.

The gnomes do not decorate their walls (I think, but what do I know, I've played all of 1 hour) and there is no awsome wonderful history generation.... or other forts... or armies... or unspeaking things that dwell in the outer darkness and has 27 heads and claws that drip acid... and there's no adventure mode. So in Gnomoria, no gnome is going to craft a goblet and then encrust it with a certain jewel that's associated with an anchient dwarf hero who's story is depicted in engravings on that cup.

So you can't make a sprawling dwarf fortress, play for centuries, then make 1 single mistake involving lava, and the fort falls into ruins. Wars happen, and then you pop into Adventure mode and go dungeon seeking to find that legendary quality cup that your favorite dwarf crafted (but died in some hysterical accident.

But, I suck at DF. I play DF like this, I create a world with wierd parameters, then embark my 7 dwarves. I start by building a tomb and coffins and I'm usually able to finish before all my dwarves are dead and buried.

So for me Gnomoria, is going to be training wheels for DF. I'm not comfortable with planning out z-layers, but Gnomorias visuals make it easy. I love how I can see what's in the ground on my z-level and all the terrain in z-levels below me. I'm going to practice making my forts (and tombs) in Gnomoria, and then I'll learn to be more proficient in DF.

But, I can't stay in Gnomoria forever, I think. Brcasue I love the depth and richness and Dwarftalks.mp3s with their awsome music and commentary about the game.

So... If you are like me and love DF but can't quite get a handle on its complexity, then join me and the gnomes for a bit... but dont delete your fort!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGnomoria is, by and large, a surprisingly deep game. Often remarked as Dwarf Fortress Lite, it is a game that puts you in charge of a community of gnomes, and gives you the task of making sure they survive and thrive. Sound easy? It's not. There are many things that need to be managed, and your first few communities are almost guaranteed to die off. The control scheme and menus are at first daunting, but once you figure out the HOW of things, it's surprisingly intuitive (Hint: Right click controls almost everything). But no matter how skilled at controlling the game you become, there will always be new things to learn. From base defense against goblins biting your hearts, to properly lighting your mines so golems don't come out of the deep, there will always be new challenges, and new ways to solve those challenges. As you attempt better structures and more elaborate designs, the enemies will react to your increased worth and start bringing armor, and bigger friends, though you will also attract more gnome migrants (Known as gnomads). So if the controls seem oppressive, don't lose hope. Look up a let's play of the game, watch for a bit, then mimic. You'll quickly figure it out, and have the time of your life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Synopsis: Inspired primarily by Dwarf Fortress (http://www.bay12games.com/dwarves/), this is an isometric 2D building game where you start with a small group of Gnomes and issue them orders to build, mine, craft, harvest and defend themselves. As you improve their new home, more Gnomes will arrive that you must feed, provide shelter for and issue orders to.

I'm really enjoying this game when I play it. I can pause at any time and issue orders, which is a real plus for me because I can use all the time I wish to plan several moves ahead. The pause feature also allows me to play this game as I do other tasks around the house or while at work.

Be advised, there are no animations as of the last time I played it. Also, the control interface still needs polish. Once you get used to it it's not too bad, but it's takes some time to achieve that comfort zone.

I also have some issue with the 2D terrain where I'm not always sure how terrain on one level will interact with the terrain above and below it, particularly with trying to place/remove dirt and stairs. Might just be me though.

Developers are making progress and have not put this one on the back-burner as is happening with too many pre-releases on Steam lately.

Usual advice is that you should peruse youtube for as much footage of the game, filtering for the most recent videos for the latest release versions, before you buy. Also try to get it on sale. When it's on sale, it's a no brainer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very fun survival/city simulator type game. People usually compare this game to Dwarf Fortress. For people who have never played or heard of Dwarf Fortress, let me explain it for you. It's a survival game, with a twist. The twist is that you control groups of people instead of being your own person.

Pros:
-Easy to get into. There is no tutorial, but a few youtube videos will get you started.

-Good graphics that don't hurt your eyes (I'm looking at you DF)

-Amazing soundtrack. You can choose the classic 8-bit songs, or remixed orchestrated songs. There is something for everyone.

-In depth job/skill system. Some gnomes are better at tasks then others. Gnomes that are bad at a skill will improve if you give them more experience.

-Trading with merchants.

-Good survival elements. You have to keep a steady supply of food and water depending on your population. The game also has all four seasons which bring challenges to overcome.

-Plenty of things to do and never gets old. You can keep a game going for hundreds of hours. It's up to you.

Cons:
- Only complaint I have with this game is that there are very few mods. Recently the game added workshop support, but mods are very small and you can only enable one mod at a time.

In conclusion, if you like survival or city builder type games, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is what indie gaming is all about.  I'd say this game is the best in it's class, but there really isn't another class quite like it.  It is one of my favorite games of all time.  A pretty incredible effort from a small development team.

This game is basically a Gnome civilization simulator.  It's unique, because you instruct your gnomes where and what to build, mine, farm, defend, patrol... in an entirely open world, and then give them specific specializations with detailed instruction lists of what to prioritize, by specific class of gnome, and then sit back and watch them do it.

It's so detailed, you actually benefit from having a dedicated brewer, that makes higher quality beer faster.  That pretty much sold me.  But that's just the beginning.   There isn't any other game I've come across with this much detail.

You will actually get pretty attached to your gnomes, and you'll inevetabily make some mistakes that will get a few of them killed, but you can just restart from a recent save file if you want.  There's virtually no limit to the creativity you can use designing your fortress, and you can make some pretty elaborate designs.

There are some con's to the game.  The graphics are pretty much sprites.  There's a lot of variety and honestly it does a great job adding to the feel of the game, and honestly you're probably not interested in this type of game for the graphics.

Second, the updates have slowed down quite a bit.  The game is still being developed, but by a single person or a very small team, and honestly it's just really slow.  In it's current state though, it still is an incredible game.  There's a few little bugs still, but nothing you can't easily work around.

Third, after surviving a few years, it becomes less dangerous.  Especially if you've researched and are smart enough to design mechanical devices to mostly insulate yourself from the progressively more dangerous monsters that continue to appear outside your door.  From that point forward, it become mostly about digging very deep for some of the best metals to be found in the game, to forge some great weapons and  armor, but at that point the mechanisms you've designed pretty much take away most of the danger....  so the end game is somewhat anti-climatic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very fun survival/city simulator type game. People usually compare this game to Dwarf Fortress. For people who have never played or heard of Dwarf Fortress, let me explain it for you. It's a survival game, with a twist. The twist is that you control groups of people instead of being your own person.

Pros:
-Easy to get into. There is no tutorial, but a few youtube videos will get you started.

-Good graphics that don't hurt your eyes (I'm looking at you DF)

-Amazing soundtrack. You can choose the classic 8-bit songs, or remixed orchestrated songs. There is something for everyone.

-In depth job/skill system. Some gnomes are better at tasks then others. Gnomes that are bad at a skill will improve if you give them more experience.

-Trading with merchants.

-Good survival elements. You have to keep a steady supply of food and water depending on your population. The game also has all four seasons which bring challenges to overcome.

-Plenty of things to do and never gets old. You can keep a game going for hundreds of hours. It's up to you.

Cons:
- Only complaint I have with this game is that there are very few mods. Recently the game added workshop support, but mods are very small and you can only enable one mod at a time.

In conclusion, if you like survival or city builder type games, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is what indie gaming is all about.  I'd say this game is the best in it's class, but there really isn't another class quite like it.  It is one of my favorite games of all time.  A pretty incredible effort from a small development team.

This game is basically a Gnome civilization simulator.  It's unique, because you instruct your gnomes where and what to build, mine, farm, defend, patrol... in an entirely open world, and then give them specific specializations with detailed instruction lists of what to prioritize, by specific class of gnome, and then sit back and watch them do it.

It's so detailed, you actually benefit from having a dedicated brewer, that makes higher quality beer faster.  That pretty much sold me.  But that's just the beginning.   There isn't any other game I've come across with this much detail.

You will actually get pretty attached to your gnomes, and you'll inevetabily make some mistakes that will get a few of them killed, but you can just restart from a recent save file if you want.  There's virtually no limit to the creativity you can use designing your fortress, and you can make some pretty elaborate designs.

There are some con's to the game.  The graphics are pretty much sprites.  There's a lot of variety and honestly it does a great job adding to the feel of the game, and honestly you're probably not interested in this type of game for the graphics.

Second, the updates have slowed down quite a bit.  The game is still being developed, but by a single person or a very small team, and honestly it's just really slow.  In it's current state though, it still is an incredible game.  There's a few little bugs still, but nothing you can't easily work around.

Third, after surviving a few years, it becomes less dangerous.  Especially if you've researched and are smart enough to design mechanical devices to mostly insulate yourself from the progressively more dangerous monsters that continue to appear outside your door.  From that point forward, it become mostly about digging very deep for some of the best metals to be found in the game, to forge some great weapons and  armor, but at that point the mechanisms you've designed pretty much take away most of the danger....  so the end game is somewhat anti-climatic.

reviewText:
I purchased this game around March 11th, It just came out of Early Access.

I want to start off by saying that this game is a lot of fun. This is your Population/Kingdom management game, where you build brick by brick, The only templates you're looking at are the workshops where you craft the materials you need to make better gear, weapons, and asthetics. You can shape the very land you live on.

The Learning curve, is pretty steep at first. When you start the game, you have nothing really guiding you on how to begin. There is help menu that provides some information, and a context menu that allows you to generate jobs for your gnomes. Here is where the game struggles a bit. As far as I can tell, Everything is great while you're above ground, dealing with your farms and animals. But once you start digging, the AI tends to hang and you have to figure out where the hang up is before your gnome decides to stop drinking and die.

Then there are the mobs... I feel that the mobs are a bit over powered in the beginning. Even at the easiest, lowest setting, a Honey Badger for example, does so much damage that while you might survive this fight, you'll have slim chances of surving the next as a beginner. Later on, there are these beetles that multiply like tribbles (StarTrek reference), and can cause your game to lag/crash. So there are still some issues that need to be worked out as far as mobs go.

Once you've gotten passed the learning curve and you've tempered your patience with the faults in the AI, you'll be able to build bigger better kingdoms.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
11/10 Would be happy getting 700+ hours of enjoyment for under $10 again.

Yes, like many people on this foruml I've topped 1000 hours on this game (inclusing 100's of hours before it was on Steam) for less than $10 1 cent an hour?

But, there are some serious caveats to my thumbs up.

The game is now released.

- Is it everything Robobob (The developer) said it would be 2-3 years ago? NO
- Is it still a very good game easily worth the pocket money price? YES
- Is it dissapopinting that magic, better enemies (and logic for combat)  and more personalized gnomes (among other things) aren't present? YES
- Can the modding community fix all these things? MOST BUT PROBABLY NOT ALL
- Should they be expected to? PROBABLY NOT

So a good solid game that falls short of what it should have been - but still a good game? YES

Are these unfulfilled promises good for the reputation of EA on Steam in general? OF COURSE THEY AREN'T


And that's the rub. Robobob's own roadmap for the game that was up until sometime in 2014 had 4 of 5 killer features down to be added and a collection of smaller stuff that would have made a difference.

In the end I think it was some design decisions very early in the game that stopped it.
The single threaded nature of the programming meaning that, with 30 gnomes, dozens of animals and perhaps 100 skeletons, goblins, mants, spiders and zombies roaming the game, it crawled to a halt and lagged.

Playing the beetles turned off helped,  lighting everywhere helps a lot. Unlike most games where lighting calcs destroy the frame rate, in this game good even lighting seems to make it run a lot smoother. Get those torches going!

A good PC can play indefinately if you sell your excess, don't encourage massive goblin invasions with ever larger taunts, turn beetles (and maybe spiders) off and keep your automaton population down.

Interestingly games like this (Clockwork Empires) that have big ambitions have developers who come right out and insist on a MINIMUM of a 4 core machine and as many threads capable of running as possible. Although Robobob has never said as much, I think it's the single core nature of the game code that hobbled it in the end.

A good game that falls short of a great game but still worth every cent of the measly 10 bucks it costs.

reviewText:
Posted originally May 8, 2015 @ 2:29am

Alright so I reviewed this game before and I still enjoy this game but the dev backed out without giving the mechanics which he had promised to give us on his dev log. There was going to be magic and enchantment crafting there is no such thing within the game atm. I would recommend it only on the fact I have enjoyed it.

I can't see anyone picking this up and playing it like I do now, beta was the time to play this game because everyone thought this guy was different making this game like a true and honest dev. That was a lie, sadly.

I cared for this game like no other beta game I have ever played but it turned out that it isn't finished, I like to think I help the community out by making these reviews not because I have too. At this current state I don't recommend this game unless the dev improves on his promises.

/ALPHA REVIEW BELOW/

Basically a easier version of Dwarf Fortress, but this game has its own identity and is fun to play. Currently Gnomoria is in beta and has solid gameplay.

Surprisingly enough, it was fun before beta also.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

the the biggest weakness point now in this game (ver. 0.9.x) is path finding and some other AI related stuff, they are buggy.
it is very easy for one player to keep 20,000 + items in the third year, then you get into the middle part of the whole gameplay. and the game client would go insanely crazy LAGGG~~~

and you may find the path finding of the in-game gnomes , they run like idiots... their job focusing point, especially those item fetching targets would be weird... the FPS drops greatly.

and, if you assign multiple storage area, and installed a lot of crates and cotton bags, some of them would empty, and gnomes would put items onto the ground of the storage area, where without a crate/barrel... this is really stupid of the game AI, how come??

that thoroughly ruined this game. stupid A.I. algorithm, and lagg issue. (well i created my own profession, and that profession contains all the jobs in-game, and i tweaked the job priority frequently for gnomes in different situations along with the in-game time passing )

and other things... yea, it is not bad. but the issues above now is a big barrier against core gameplay... and the game got no update for months! this stupid bug been there for so many weeks...

i cannot vote GOOD" for this game..."
voteText: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dwarf fortress inspired, but Gnomoria has definitely come into its own. This game has been a great ride, one of the first early access games I supported. Every update brought more fun and more experimentation to do, different ways for my gnomes to thrive or get brutally murdered.

I have watched my gnomes toil away so many different ways. From slaving away building a giant gnome out of a mountain range to building an upside down pyramid. I have watched golbins tear apart my guards and skeletons eviscerate my miners.

I have built a magnificent palace for them and trading posts. Barracks and factories! Farmlands and military states! There's so many ways to play this game it's crazy. Robotronic has put heart and soul into this game over the years and it shows! I am grateful that I got to experience the journey!

If you like building games, or army games, or economic games, or just like watching things die, this game is for you! Gnomoria will frustrate you and entertain you, but always leave you with a fulfilled feeling no matter the outcomes.
voteText: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a highly underrated game, there's nothing quite like Gnomoria. Actually there's tons of games similar, but nothing as good as this.

Sure your gnome can get stuck 15 stories high because they deleted the floor the wrong way, or dig their own graves -30 bellow when trying to make stairs, but it's still very fun to build mighty walls and giant structures that you dreamed in a block world!

Very addicting, very fun, takes some time to get the swing of it but it's definitly a must have!

I recommend peaceful mode ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gnomoria is a bit like Dwarf Fortress-Lite with cute isometric graphics. Don't get me wrong, it's not just a DF clone. It's got a flavor all its own and the learning curve is significanly easier than DF.

The developer communicates with the community regularly via the official forums and updates to the indev beta branch are pretty regular. Right now the dev is working on getting the modding platform all worked out so there haven't been content updates in awhile, but the game has a lot of depth already.

Really, this game is incredibly fun and you should pick it up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm writing this review for gnomoria after reading a negative review about it still being in early access after all this time. I find that very misleading, yes its in early access but should it be there? EA games could learn a lot from this game. Even in early access gnomoria is more finished than most if not all EA games.
In fact should EA games stand for electronic arts or Early Access games!
As far as I am concerned this game is Finished and shouldn't be early access, he just doesn't seem to want to stop working on it! does that deserve a negative review?
I keep falling for the same thing, thinking how good an early access game looks. I buy it and then what progress seems to slow to a crawl or just stop.
I dont play gnomoria that much now, mostly because its a serious time sink. With that in mind look at how long most reviewers have played it for!
I am not comparing game play, but I have played GTA V for 71 hours and I'm bored, GTA price £40. Gnomoria 276 hours and I cant play it anymore because it takes way too much of my time, price £5.99.
OK the graphics suck, it isn't simple to learn and it can be frustrating. But this is a damn good little game and worth every penny.
Sorry rant over.
