reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who really enjoys the depth of Dwarf Fortress as far as a city builder and management game goes, this game really captures the style of game that Dwarf Fortress is, but in a much more simplified and pretty way. Now that's not going as far as to say it's a better game, but if you prefer graphics over game depth, then this is the game for you.

It's soundtrack is just incredible and very cute, happy sounding generally. The tiles and sprites are really adorable, in my opinion, and it's very easy to manage, especially with the mouse controls.

It still doesn't beat Dwarf Fortress, but if I'm not up for insane levels of management, this is the game I go to!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Graphics make me feel like it's 1993. No instructions and super confusing at first. But what an awesome soundtrack (if not repetitive). Basically it's a fun base building game. You control gnomes by assigning tasks, job roles, and managing queues. You'll have to dig down and mine for resources in an almost endless amount of depths. Skeletons, golems, and spookies come up to attack from below. Goblins, orcs, and antmen come at you on the surface.

Most people will hate the difficulty. If you get past that it will completely take your soul.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was bored waiting for Banished, so my fiance kindly gifted this game to me without me knowing. I am usually a stickler for graphics in today's age of technology in games. Even with the graphics it is a very indepth game of managing and stragery. I love how you have a choice to play peacefully or have the option to defend from mobs both inside and outside of the area you are building. Of course I chose peacefully, because the biggest downfall I've seen so far is no tutorial. It just throws you out there with a not so helpful help tab once you click Esc. Knowing this I would suggest a good beginner's guide, Youtube Let's play, or Wiki. Wiki helped me more than the others.

Pros for me:
The choice to play just building or have combat.
You can micro manage like heck in this game.
They have Yaks (Dang you Guild Wars 1)!
A wide variety of things to buildfrom chairs, floors, walls, decor...and on and on
Where you can take your imagination and create some interesting Castles, underground city, and the only limitation is your imagination, water, and floor allowance (which I've not run into yet), Um and if you have resources to do such.
The price. Great price for the game style and the amount of choice you have (seen more costly games that way less choice).

Cons:
Well to be honest, only few so far.
The graphics (that's me and my fickle self)
How slow things are done
And it's addictive and I lost time playing it (You play it and you say just a few more things and the next thing you know it has been literally hours since you took a break).
And the rough way they slap you in the game with no tutorial, the help tab is pretty much useless in my opinion.

And there is not enough hours in the day to play it....oh wait..not the game's bad..my bad!

I would honestly rate this game an 8.5 out 10. And so you know I rarely rate any game that high.

This game is very addictive when youre still discovering new things, but it doesnt go anywhere once youve gotten the hang of building a successful city, and there arent any animations. The mechanics are solid, for the most part, and have much more depth and complexity than similar releases these days, plus the developers fix bugs quickly, so if youre into city builders and resource management games, youll dig Gnomoria.

The first several times you play it you will be slaughtered brutally, and learning how to balance combat with economy is fun. The only real problem, which i mostly attribute to it being early access"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This little game is relentlessly compared to Dwarf Fortress, and it is a just comparison.

The likeness to dwarf fortress is obvious in many ways. The game is not as deep as dwarf fortress but has one MAJOR advantage; The game is designed to not fry your brain with ASCII and fey moods, tantrum spirals or catsplosions.

It has some nifty automation features and an isometric GUI with mouse navigable menus . Not DF's arbitrary keyboard shotcuts and terrible ....... can we call them graphics?

If u had any love for DF at all, but just didnt want to commit weeks to learning WTF you are looking at, then Gnomoria is worth a go. You could even get this to warm you up for DF :P.

The game is perfectly playable in current state and updates are very regular and well documented. The developer is friendly and makes time to answer questions about updates or technical issues. With time i hope its depth will rival DF's!

All round, a nice little management game. 7/10

(P.S. my steam playtime is 0hours as i bought the game before steam early access but much time has been invested into this game)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off: be aware that this game has a select target audience.  It is essentially Dwarf Fortress Lite, and therefore a micromanagement game.  This means you will spend a lot of time in menus, messing with lots of stuff to get your dudes doing what you wnat them to.  However, where Dwarf Fortress has a learning curve about like a brick wall, This game's curve, while still steep, is not near as bad.  The UI is fairly intuitive, and once you have an idea of what you want to do, getting it done is usually fairly straightforward.  A starter quest system or some other form of tutorial for the game would be extremely useful in indicating your priorities and helping fortresses to actually survive their first year (my first didn't), but unfortunately all that is availabe at the moment are youtube videos.

All in all, I would reccomend Gnomoria to anyone willing to take the time to learn how to play, as it is quite enjoyable at that point.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun little game. Awesome how you can have almost total control over your map settings, like how big it is and how strong your enemies are, etc. This makes it so you can play the game exactly how YOU want to play it. Love how many different possibilities to build there are. You can build all kinds of rooms and furniture.

One thing I strongly dislike about it, though, is that it is very hard to learn the controls and how to play the game in general. I had to watch a 30 minute tutorial video on YouTube to even start playing. But once I did get the hang of it, it is pretty straight forward. (I recommend changing your hotkeys in the settings!) Also, music gets annoying.

I think many things can be improved. This game is, however, still under development! Considering, this game is awesome and has so much stuff! It's hard to tell how long certain tasks will take. Your crops have no timer, so you can't tell how long until fully grown, not even a graphic to show growth level. One day, they just pop up fully grown. Mine took like....8 or 9 game days to fully grow...I thought this was a bug at first, preventing my crops to grow! Same with your gnomes sleeping, I thought they were glitched and wouldn't wake up....turns out they just needed to sleep longer.

All things considered....the game is worth the money to me so far. I have just purchased it today, though. I'm looking forward to future game updates, and hoping the developers make a lot of needed changes!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really enjoyed this game. It's got some great balancing and challenge mechanics that allow you to take your time and progress at a pace you can handle. Get too greedy with your digging or grow your city without proper protection and deal with the consequences. Some features I really love is having individual gnomes with names that you can assign jobs, track their lives and achievements through the seasons. See how many goblins they can slay and keep them alive when they get injured.

I had a gnome called Jazz that had an arm and both legs cut off. He had served my kingdom well since its inception so I built him his own bedroom and workshop right next to each other. He then became my kingdoms master jeweler until my entire kingdom was wiped out by ogres and goblins. I was getting worse and worse attacks because master Jazz was making the best jewlery in the lands, which raised my kingdom value enough to see hordes rushing me.

You can farm crops, tend to livestock, craft all kinds of furniture and weapons and armour all which take into account minute details about what its components are and the quality of construction.

You can also terraform the lands to suit your purposes, make a base inside a mountain or build a castle whatever tickles your fancy.

You do not control your gnomes directly, rather control is done in 2 stages. First you give gnomes tasks they are allowed to perform like chopping trees. Then when you assign a tree to be felled the most available gnome runs over and does it. This cuts the micromanagement to a level you can decide which is great. You can micromanage every task to happen straight away or just set a task and forget about it, someone will fix it later. This is the opposite to facebook/browser style village games where you have to do every little thing yourself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beautiful game and highly addictive.

Gnomoria is the work of one man, RoboBob, and is inspired by games like Dwarf Fortress. RoboBob updates the game twice or thrice per month and is in direct contact with the community. While it takes some time to get used to the game mechanics and UI, once you are there it plays very good.

Games like this are the reason why Early Access and Indie games are good for the PC gaming industry. It feels to me almost a finished game and it has provided much more enjoyment than AAA games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun little game. Awesome how you can have almost total control over your map settings, like how big it is and how strong your enemies are, etc. This makes it so you can play the game exactly how YOU want to play it. Love how many different possibilities to build there are. You can build all kinds of rooms and furniture.

One thing I strongly dislike about it, though, is that it is very hard to learn the controls and how to play the game in general. I had to watch a 30 minute tutorial video on YouTube to even start playing. But once I did get the hang of it, it is pretty straight forward. (I recommend changing your hotkeys in the settings!) Also, music gets annoying.

I think many things can be improved. This game is, however, still under development! Considering, this game is awesome and has so much stuff! It's hard to tell how long certain tasks will take. Your crops have no timer, so you can't tell how long until fully grown, not even a graphic to show growth level. One day, they just pop up fully grown. Mine took like....8 or 9 game days to fully grow...I thought this was a bug at first, preventing my crops to grow! Same with your gnomes sleeping, I thought they were glitched and wouldn't wake up....turns out they just needed to sleep longer.

All things considered....the game is worth the money to me so far. I have just purchased it today, though. I'm looking forward to future game updates, and hoping the developers make a lot of needed changes!

Early Access Review

Tried Dwarf Fortress. Had to look up a wiki for controls and being able to tell what stuff is before even having to look up a wiki for gameplay stuff. Obviously you can get your head into it but thats an investment i wasnt ready to make. Ill spare you a lengthy rant about a free game :p

Highly recommended if you like any type of base/village building/managing/defending sim stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like Dwarf fortress but want a easier to learn game? Want more graphics? Like a active modding community?  Then get this. You can play completely with assignable hotkeys and/or GUI mouse controls.

You start off with area to start your gnome colony in.From there you have to assign jobs for your gnomes,set up farms,plant seeds,gather resources,etc. Build your homes/kingdom both above ground and/or below.Mine materials,craft them into various things,keep food and water stockpiles etc. Its pretty much like what any new colony would have to do in order to survive.

Lots of fun,(remember its still in alpha/beta) a good amount of growing content,responsive Dev that tweaks the game based on community feedback,weekly -biweekly updates. Lots of fun for hours on end. Your choice of playing pure survival with no hostiles (peacemode) or switching to or started normal mode which has everything in peacemode but with hostiles.

if you like what you read then do yourself a favor and get it.

reviewText: First of all i would like to say that i realy loved this game. Ive played well over the amount of time I originally was intending.  With that being said, I am fully dissapointed with the final release, we were told that magic would be added, and wasnt, we were told that gnomes would have more personal goals and actually leave if those goals were not met. as well as some other things.  The final version has been left up to the modders to finnsh. This practice in my opinion is lazy. Considering how long we had to wait for patches and updates, this practice is a slap in the face to all the fans of the game.  I understand it is one developer, and i understand he has a life. But if you tell us one thing and then do another your no better then all the othe companies that took our money and said eff it.  Please dont let this be the end of the devlopment and realy on modders to do the work, you turn them into free labor and make yourself look like alazy doosh in the process. Being a developer myself I understand the need to know when to stop a project.  I also know that saying one thing and doing another is an awful way to go about your game.  EA has done it, SquareEnix has done it, this does not give you the right to do it.  Untill these practices have ceased the Indie community will be no better then the AAA community. Dont slap your fans in the face and be a lazy devoloper, mods are fun but content from the developer is better. I will recomened this game but I do not believe it is any better at full realese then it was when it was put on for early access.  Dont let this stand.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played only 5 minutes so far, I know I should to more research but honestly, this game is hard to understand, I don't like tutorials for most games but this is one of those times where a tutorial is NEEDED.

There don't seem to be any animations leaving a dull feeling.

It's obvious this game was most likey inspired by some overly hyped game that died after it was released but I can see this was going to take a Terraria route. Take what you have, change one thing, that trainslates into a completely different game.

Terraria went into a 2D side scrolling game that is better than what it was based on (Or at least now it is) The thing is, even if you knew nothing about how to do things, it was still easy to learn through the gameplay.

This game took the idea that Terraria had, mixed it with a bit of the Sims, and added a top down perspective.

It worked out, but the problem is it needs a tutorial, it falls flat without one and not wanting to try and learn how to play it mostly due it being hard to understand (Like Towns is.) It's makes me feel lost, alone, confused, and a bit frustrated.

It's not that I don't WANT to learn as I play, that's real fun to do, it's just that you leave me with nothing but my own thoughts, like trying to figure out how to lockpick a door, I need SOME form of a hint.

Overall, it looks good so far, I can't give an opinion, I'll change my thoughts and the review when I learn and play this game more extensively, right now I'm not in the mood to spend an hour trying to learn how to get the people to do things.

reviewText:
This game may look like Dwarf Fortress on the outside, but you're going to find out really fast that this is more like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ son that nobody in the family ever talks about.

Here are the reasons why I am hating on this game:

Building anything in this game takes FOREVER.  Even if you have all of the base materials Queue'd up, it still manages to find a way to take a long time.  You literally have to go one by one building this thing here and then that thing there.  God forbid if you Queue up a few beds and then try to make 2 pieces of armor.

Monsters can spawn from dark areas within the inside of your town. I don't agree with this choice because it forces you to build torches EVERYWHERE.  Plus I feel as if it loses the immersion for me.  In Dwarf Fortress there was always a reason for everything.  Goblins came from the town nearby and raided you.  If you picked a location close to a haunted mountainside Cavern then you can bet that undead monsters will begin to appear by your Fortress.

Gnomoria has no tutorial or anything that tells you what you need to play this game.  New players will be absolutely LOST.  Even if you have played Dwarf Fortress before you will still have some learning curve as this does not play exactly the same way.  If you haven't played Dwarf Fortress, you better start reading the wiki and learn to ask nicely on the forums how 2 play game.

You don't know what is going on during the fights.  You have to click on the events and find out what is going on by pausing the action and read through a few menus (at the top of the screen).  Even in Dwarf Fortress with its lack of graphical representation still allowed you to see how well the fight was going by simply making your character blink and blink faster if they were dying and cover the Dwarves with blood.   Loads of times I have lost a Gnome simply because I thought the fight was going well, but in fact it wasn't.

I know that the more worth your Great Hall is the greater your chances of getting more Gnomes to come settle will be.  However I went and I built that stupid Great Hall up and I received 1 extra Gnome.... just 1.

But there are a couple of positives:

The graphics are prettier than Dwarf Fortress.

I do like the military system in which you gain perks for certain formations and also what type of soldier you want them to be.

https://youtu.be/B8xYjPF7Pnk

TLDR: Playing this game actually makes me feel like going back to playing Dwarf Fortress.  I hate comparing any game to another but the comparison has to be drawn since these 2 games are extremely alike in a lot of ways.   In fact just do yourself a favor and instead support the guys who are developing Dwarf Fortress and play that game.  It's way more immersive and there are plenty more things to do in that game without feeling bogged down or frustrated.
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A neutral review. As of 25/05/2015

The game has been in development for years and frankly it still needs years given the current progress being made before it's ready for release in my opinion. A fun ride but it's very bumpy.

The cons.
1. Some crashes still exist (although I haven't been plagued with them myself)
2. Pathfinding is awkward at best due to the next problemVVV
3.Fail states" exist
date: if you deconstruct a well sometimes the gnomes bug out trying to pick up the deconstructed parts or something. Or if you mine in the "wrong" way you can isolate your miners who eventually die of thirst
recommended: thus killing your colony before it even begins.\n4. Lack of information about what things do. It's hard to know when it's a good time to "tech" up and when the build defenses
hoursPlayed: do I want extra armour? I don't know. Do I want to fight that bear? I don't know.\n5. Learning curve is steep and doesn't show signs of slowing down after 14 hours of play. Yes this is a con.\n6. Under constant attack
voteText: dealing with constant attacks from things gets annoying
helpfulPercent: and feels like i'm on firefighting duty rather than building a colony or town.\n7. Combat system is bad sad bad
votesHelpful:
lots of little things you can forget can bite you in the behind later on. The lack of individual control over the gnomes feels especially frustrating here.
8. Animations are incredibly lacking if even present. Understandable but not acceptable.
9. Camera view is awkward. Not a huge problem but at times it becomes a hindrance being stuck in diagonal view.

Pros.
1. Very satisfying figuring out problems and optimising things.
2. Lots of replayability
votesTotal: if you can figure out the issues with the game it's not that bad to play.\n3. Balancing what to build and when is quite fun
votesFunny: and is probably one of the main reasons people play the game. Just because I haven't figured out the optimal way doesn't mean you can't.\n4. Customisation options are quite varied
commentsCount:
provided you can survive long enough to reach them.
5. The game is still being worked on despite being several years in the works which says something about the dedication of the developers.
6. Lots of ways to play the game...after a certain point.
7. You have a lot of control over how the gnomes behave
column16: granted the interface for controlling them is very very awkward
column17:
you do technically have a lot of say over how they behave.


Conclusion clunky controls
column18:
annoying combat mechanics and general lack of polish means this game should be avoided until it's complete.
Lack of information to the player and any real feedback on what they're doing increases the learning time required to get the basics understood.
Proceed at your own risk to investment in time.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: Look at the time of the last Update. February 2015 and it was a minscule Update at that. If it ever gets finished (BIG IF) then you should buy this game. But honestly, that is not going to happen. This game is dead in the water

*********************************************************************

I have had this game for a while and came to it because i did not have the time to dedicate to Dwarf Fortress and also wanted something with more intuitive control system and at least minimal graphics.

My initial expectations were met but each time i pick up the game (after 3-6 months off) i come to find very little has changed of value. Development has slowed to the point where it is a legitimate shock when there is an update and then disappointment when you discover that what is an 'Update' to this Dev would be a tinkering of the system in any other game.

If, and thats a BIG if, it gets released then it might be worth buying but it is essentially dead in the water and has been for quite some time.

reviewText:
Dwarf fortress clone. Pretty solid at its core.

The graphics are better, but still very basic. The lack of any animation is a bit disappointing.
If the devs tie up all the loose ends, this could be a really fun game to spend a lot of hours on.

The cumbersome UI is one of the major drawbacks of this game. Performing actions, or even getting access to basic information is often difficult if not impossible. However, the UI is much prettier and more intuitive.

Bugs and glitches are prevalent throughout the game. Some bugs are merely annoying, while other totally ruin your game.

All in all, the game feels 90% consumer-ready.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will drain away many hours of your life.

Nevermind the early access designation.  This game has been completely playable for a couple years, and has been getting updated/bug fixes and new features regularly for years.

The game was originally posted on Desura(Where I bought it), but desura has gone defunct, and now its here on steam.

To be honest, Im not sure why its designated early access.  The game functions as well as any finished product.  Possibly because the developer still has big plans for this game yet.  I dont know.

There is no reason not to get this game.   Its underpriced at $7.99.   I think I payed $20 for it over a year ago.
No regrets. no complaints.

About the Game:  It does have a a somewhat steep learning curve, and you will find yourself starting over alot until you get a system figured out.  But you wont find it discouraging at all.  Its actually gratifying to come up with your own methods of survival.  Do you build farms right away? Or rely on foraging for food in the first year.  Do you build a well?  Or rely on yakmilk for drink.  Do you build a wall and limit your resources in exchange for safety?  Or do you risk your gnomes to dangers of the wild to have access to to everything.  Do you begin training your militia right away or wait til you have secured your sustenance for the coming years.   How deep do you delve early on to find minerals underground? because the deeper you go, the more dangerous it becomes for mining...

Once you have secrued your sources of basic sustenence for survival, and trained up a basic militia to guard against wild animals and goblin attacks..   you can then begin constructing your ... whatever you can imagine.  Castles....  underground complexes...    This game is like a minecraft meets dwarf fortress...

I have one friend here on steam who I showed this game to. He now has over 900 hours of playtime in Gnomoria.  I have alot of time in ti myself, but it was mostly before it came to steam.


I recommend watching a few 'lets play gnomoria on youtube first to get a feel for what this game really looks like."
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now, I may haven't played this for a while, but it is FUN!

You basically start out with 9 gnomes, food, water, and 2 yak. You have to make a home for all of the gnomes to live in, a hospital, dormatorys, personal quarters, etc. You farm, set up groves to farm trees, and set up some pastures for your animals. You can trade with other kingdoms once you have a trading stall. I'd recommend starting a house in the mines, so its easier.

Pros-
Nice and fun gameplay
OK graphics
Easy to play when you learn controls

Cons-
When you battle a hostile mob with 5 gnomes, you WILL lose 1 if its early game
Controls are hard to get used to
Soundtrack isn't the best thing in the world

I hope you found this review useful!

-Mineman021

P.S. Look on the Wikia for more info on the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great, friendly approuch to the increasingly popular Dwarf Fortress genre.
The UI is fantastic in comparison to other similar games and makes it easy to learn some of the quirks (however more tooltips and such would be more helpful).
The updates have yet to disappoint me, which keeps me interested until it is finished.
Big plus for the interchangeable soundtrack (You can change between both Orchestral and Chiptune style).

I really don't have that much to say other than that this is ABSOLUTELY worth the money, and is right now one of the best of its kind. That says a lot about this game, considering the vast amount of similar games that are already out or coming out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rating: 3 of 10

I just started and already hate it.

# Bad

* When you start a new game loadings take alots of time (~15 minutes).
* Saving pauses the game for few secs and game remains paused after the save.
* The units dont walk, they just teleport from tile to tile. It looks bad.
* Its a pain to place stairs and ramps underground. Did the devs ever played this game?
* The default music is very annoying. The orchestral music is not that bad.
* To build something you have to left click, release, drag and click again instead of holding mouse button, drag and release.
* Its hard to see where your placing the objects. Most of time you missplace objects.

# Good

* Alots of gameplay content and you can configure everything you can imagine.

# Advice:

* Go play Rimworld.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

3/10 Get it for the graphics, and on sale only.

First off, those cute little Gnomes you see, are all made of solid stone. They are not animated. Nothing is animated.

It is a cute game for about 10 minutes, then you have to start over usually. For some unknown reason, all of the sudden all of your gnomes will become unresponsive. There are no hints or clues on what to do next,,,, Are they hungary? Are they out of tasks? Are they on drugs?

i see it on sale today, it seems like a fair price. i feel i got $2 before it became completely ignored by me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update: Over a year later and the AI still isn't fixed. For example, when you start a new game you will have 2 yaks and 1 rancher. If you assign an area for ranching, the rancher will not put the yaks in the ranch and start caring for them. Honestly, I don't understand how something so basic can still be broken this far into the development cycle.

I really wanted to like this game. The concept is great, and I was in love with the idea of building, staffing, and defending my own fortress city.

Unfortunately, the AI is just not there, and without the ability to directly command the gnomes, it is often difficult to complete tasks.

In the mid to late game, you will find yourself frantically trying to get your gnomes to do basic tasks like craft critical ingredients, and nothing you do will convince them to do it.

reviewText:
New review:

1.0 is out. It's fun, but still game-breaking bugs and, worstly, several design issues. No depth in the game. As some other reviewer perfectly described, Gnomoria is just a paid tutorial to Dwarf Fortress (even when Gnomoria has no tutorial itself).

Old review:

Great potential, specially if you are planning to learn something more affordable before jumping to Dwarf Fortress, but too buggy at this present state (0.9.17). It's frustrating when you spend hours trying to do a thing that you are doing it right but it's just a bug in the game. My gnomes nearly die of thirst even when I had a brewery, nearly 200 fruits, an order of making a minimum of 100 wine, two or three gnomes with the brewery profession, and brewery at highest priority. Assigning to a gnome didn't work, the one who made all the wine in the settlement before, so I had to manually delete all his other profesions. And this is only one of workshops that suddenly stops working for no apparent reason.

I'll check again the game when it's 1.0. This game will be a joy when everything is working. But until it's fixed and playable, better spend your time learning Dwarf Fortress.

Edit: Seems the developer has become disinterested in the game and is more concerned about pricing structure post-release than actually releasing a game that doen't habitually crash. Really fun concept, extremely poor and greedy execution.

reviewText: I tried to make a mine twice in this game. There is no easy way to make a hole in the ground your gnomes can actually climb out of. Partly, the problem is actually being able to see, since the game forces you into an isometric view. The game needs ladders from the beginning, or a tool that makes a multilevel ramp. As in, click & drag and the ramp goes further and further down, instead of making a row of ramps...

reviewText:
Bought this in 2013 in Early Access. It released this year finally. It took 4 minutes to generate a map that had graphics similar to an early 80's videogame console system. It looks like it is running at about 1 or 2 frames per second.

There is no tutorial. There was supposed to be a tutorial. Don't buy this game unless you already know how to play this game.

It took 20 seconds to save my game before exiting.

Maybe when I load it up next time to get my last 2 trading cards, my gnomes will have figured out how to pick up the logs from the trees they cut down. If the tutorial has been put in by then, maybe I will figure out how to make them do it.
